events.label: Sep 19, 2025
events.note: The House passes a short-term Continuing Resolution (CR). The Senate does not advance the measure amid disagreements over spending priorities (as of Oct 2025).

events.label: Sep 30, 2025
events.note: The Senate fails to advance competing funding proposals; a lapse in funding is expected at 12:01 a.m. EDT on Oct 1 (as of Oct 2025).

events.label: Oct 1, 2025 (12:01 am EDT)
events.note: Federal funding expires at 12:01 a.m. EDT, triggering a partial government shutdown. Essential services continue; many employees are furloughed or working without pay (as of Oct 2025).
events.cost: See economic_loss banner for growth impact estimate (as of Oct 2025).

events.label: Oct 1, 2025
events.note: Senate leaders discuss shorter-term funding options on the floor; no agreement is reached. Both Republican and Democratic versions of stopgap measures fail procedural votes (as of Oct 2025).

events.label: Oct 1, 2025
events.note: Markets fluctuate as participants weigh the potential economic fallout; some haven assets gain, while equities and risk assets show volatility (as of Oct 2025).

events.label: Oct 2, 2025
events.note: The Senate does not pass any funding legislation; the partial shutdown continues into a second day (as of Oct 2025).

events.label: Oct 2, 2025
events.note: The Department of Education reviews concerns about automated “out-of-office” messaging changes and guidance during shutdown (as of Oct 2025).

events.label: Oct 3, 2025
events.note: The House is in recess while negotiations stall; the shutdown remains unresolved (as of Oct 2025).

events.label: Oct 5, 2025
events.note: Day 5 of the shutdown: limited operations continue where authorized, but many agencies are largely halted (as of Oct 2025).

events.label: Oct 6, 2025
events.note: The Senate again fails to advance a stopgap funding bill (requiring 60 votes); the White House presses for a bipartisan deal (as of Oct 2025).

events.label: Oct 7, 2025
events.note: The White House circulates a memo saying there is no guarantee of back pay for furloughed workers, contradicting long-standing norms (as of Oct 2025).

events.label: Oct 8, 2025
events.note: Senate again fails to adopt funding measures; criticisms intensify that the White House is refusing to negotiate until the government is reopened. :contentReference[oaicite:0]{index=0}

events.label: Oct 8, 2025
events.note: Some airports begin reporting delays due to staffing shortfalls (especially among air traffic controllers) as the shutdown carries on. :contentReference[oaicite:1]{index=1}

events.label: Oct 9, 2025
events.note: President announces target cuts to programs favored by Democrats in response to the ongoing shutdown. :contentReference[oaicite:2]{index=2}

events.label: Oct 10, 2025
events.note: Federal employees receive partial pay for previously worked days, but new paychecks are withheld during the shutdown. :contentReference[oaicite:3]{index=3}

events.label: Oct 12, 2025
events.note: Smithsonian museums and National Zoo announce closures for the remainder of the shutdown due to depletion of carryover funds. :contentReference[oaicite:4]{index=4}
